label: Carl the Consumer
narrative: A 9-5 software engineer at a company (bank, healthcare, etc.). Utilizes open-source software to create software and/or other products which include open-source as building blocks. He does not make open-source contributions but consumes software as part of her job. Spends most of the day in an IDE writing software and on occasion gets a report from security about dependency vulnerabilities in the software.

goals: Release features to hit business deadlines is priority, but understands need to follow compliance and policy requirements.
Wants to make security team satisfied with project by resolving any security vulnerabilities which have remediation deadlines, security control implementations, etc.
Wants to determine and understand security posture of the open source software consumed to manage risks and compliance.
likes: Policy and compliance feedback or requirements earlier in the SDLC loop so that it isn't discovered right before the deadline.
dislikes: Inability to drive meaningful change within the larger organization so is at the whims of policies and processes such as security requirements.
Inconsistency and wide variances in security quality of project dependencies. Wide range of development practices in open-source make it difficult to assess and understand.

product: Would like to see information about compliance (security, EOL, etc.) in the tools and workflows already using (IDE, CLI, etc.).
Create forward-thinking best practices and standards to help developers make decisions proactively in securing software rather than reactive.
Provide data (sources) which provide insight into security qualities of various open-source projects.
Create environment for developing tools to automatically assess and/or improve the security quality of open-source projects.
education: Outside of basic annual or quarterly security training, does not have access to learning materials for identifying common attacks (sql injection, etc.).
Interpretation of complicated jargon and requirements to help create issues in open source dependencies for improvements to security and compliance.
Provide guidelines and recommendations for methods of exchanging information, fostering adoption through interoperable methods.
communications: Provide ammunition and materials to help developer push for change.

OpenSSF through its work inhelping define and collaborate on controls, standards, best practices, and regulations drive industry and community change to be adopted at larger and often slower moving enterprises.
Can help facilitate where a supply chain inherently involves multiple entities which need to interact and utilize
